Award.AwardTitle: U.S.-India International Collaborative Research and Training for Computer Science Students
Award.AbstractNarration:
Rajiv Gandhi
OISE- 1050968

U.S.-India International Collaborative Research and Training for Computer Science Students

This international collaborative research and training award to Computer Science Professor Rajiv Gandhi will provide a unique research and educational experience in Mumbai, India for four promising computer science students from Rutgers University-Camden. The students along with the PI will work on Approximation Algorithms for NP-hard problems (Non-deterministic Polynomial Time) with mentors Suneeta Sane, Professor and Head, Computer Technology Department, Veermate Jijabai Technological Institute (VJTI) and faculty at the School of Technology and Computer Science, Tata Institute of Fundamental Research. The problems that the group intends to work on arise in ad hoc and storage area networks.

Intellectual Merit- Scheduling problems play a central role in the design of communication networks. Many of these problems are NP-hard and hence efficient algorithms that produce near-optimal solutions are of intrinsic importance. Such algorithms can have significant impact on the performance of the networks in terms of scalability and the usage of valuable resources such as bandwidth (and power, in case of ad hoc networks).

Broader Impacts- The PI joined the faculty at Rutgers University Camden, a liberal arts institution, in order to focus on undergraduate education. The core component of the proposed project is to provide an international research and education experience to students at Rutgers University Camden. All students participating in this project are expected to pursue graduate studies. As two of the international collaborators are women, this is likely to have the additional positive impact on the long-term goals of the participating female students in this project.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit :

During the grant period the participants worked on the following intractable scheduling problem: There is a single machine that can process at most one job at a time. There are n jobs to be processed, with each job having a release time (time at which the job is available), processing time, and a weight. The objective is to obtain a non-preemptive schedule such that the total weighted completion times of jobs is minimized. In joint work with students James Davis and Vijay Kothari, we obtained combinatorial algorithms for the problem in offline as well as online settings. While our algorithms do not improve the best possible bounds for the problem, they do shed light on the most natural linear programming relaxation for the problem.

Sean Lowen (a freshmen then) worked on fairly advanced topics such as cut problems and prepared an excellent presentation on the Multiway cut problem. His presentation can be found at: http://crab.rutgers.edu/~rajivg/studentTalks/multiwayCut.pdf . He presented this in the colloquium series in the CS department at Rutgers-Camden.

Elaine Zamora worked on the data migration problem in which in order to continue providing efficient service, the load across disks need to be rebalanced in response to changes in data access patterns.

The PI also worked on some covering optimization problems with collaborators at research institutions in India.

 

Broader Impact :

The students got an opportunity to interact with faculty and students in India. These interactions were mutually beneficial to both the US students as well as students in India.

The PI also volunteered his time by working with high school students in Mumbai on weekends. As a side effect of these meetings, three female high school sophomore students took two months off from school to attend the Summer Program in Theoretical Computer Science (http://rajivgandhics.wordpress.com) at Princeton University. These students had no exposure to Computer Science before they attended the meetings with the PI, but now they seem to be quite interested in studying Computer Science.

The three US students (Vijay Kothari, Sean Lowen, Elaine Zamora) working with the PI during this grant period are now pursuing their studies at some of the top institutions in the country.
